title: Shock development after ABC star Antoinette Lattouf was dumped from the airwaves just days into her new job
text:
Antoinette Lattouf was dismissed from the ABCShe'd shared posts criticising the Israeli Defence Forces A protester vandalised the ABC's Perth office in response READ MORE: Antoinette Lattouf is suing the ABC for unfair dismissal
ABC Radio‚Äôs Perth office has been vandalised by a pro-Palestine supporter after Antoinette Lattouf was axed from ABC Sydney Mornings.
Lattouf was dismissed as the ABC‚Äôs temporary presenter in Sydney on Wednesday over a series of social media posts criticising the Israeli Defence Forces.
In her posts, Lattouf questioned the legitimacy of footage filmed at a pro-Palestine rally in front of the Sydney Opera House where people were heard chanting ‚Äògas the Jews‚Äô and accused the IDF of rape during raids of the Gaza Strip.
A flood of complaints from the ABC‚Äôs Jewish listeners reached chairwoman Ita Buttrose, leading to Lattouf being fired.
In the early hours of Sunday morning, a protester accused the ABC of ‚Äòcensorship‚Äô and called the reason for Lattouf‚Äôs termination ‚Äòan affront to the very idea of journalistic integrity‚Äô.
Antoinette Lattouf (above) was fired from the ABC for sharing numerous posts criticising the Israeli Defense Forces online
Footage sent to The Australian showed a vandal wearing a white headscarf spray-painting over the ABC Radio logo at the broadcaster‚Äôs Fielder Street office.
‚ÄòBoycott ‚Äì justice for Antoinette,‚Äô they wrote.
The protester then wrote ‚Äòfree Palestine‚Äô on the building‚Äôs next window.
‚ÄòDirect action was taken against the ABC Radio office in Boorloo/Perth to protest [the] unjust firing of Antoinette Lattouf over her factual reporting of the Israeli genocide against the people of Palestine,‚Äô a message alongside the clip read.
‚ÄòThis act of censorship by the ABC management is an affront to the very idea of journalistic integrity.
‚ÄòWhile the ABC cower in the face of external pressure, 100 journalists have been killed while reporting on the genocide being committed by the state of Israel.‚Äô
It follows a similar graffiti protest at the ABC‚Äôs Melbourne Headquarters on Friday.
The protest has no yet been reported to Western Australia Police.
A pro-Palestine protester filmed themself vandalising the ABC‚Äôs Perth office (above), writing ‚Äòboycott ‚Äì justice for Antoinette‚Äô
The vandalism (above) which accused the broadcaster of ‚Äòcensorship‚Äô was not reported to police
On Thursday Lattouf shared she was ‚Äòdisappointed‚Äô in the ABC and believes she was ‚Äòterminated unlawfully‚Äô.
‚ÄòThis is not a win for journalism or critical, fair thinking,‚Äô she said.
Lattouf has since lodged an application with Fair Work.
Lattouf had been filling in for Sarah Macdonald as host of the ABC Sydney Mornings radio program last week but was told on Wednesday she was no longer needed for her shifts on Thursday and Friday.
‚ÄòABC Sydney casual presenter Antoinette Lattouf will not be back on air for her remaining two shifts this week,‚Äô an ABC spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia.
Her submission to the Fair Work Commission alleges she was fired after sharing an Instagram post from Human Rights Watch, which breached the ABC‚Äôs policies.
It also alleges ABC Managing Director David Anderson had made the decision to terminate Lattouf‚Äôs position at the national broadcaster.
Daily Mail Australia contacted the ABC for comment.

author: Oliver Adey
title: Health rounds: GLP-1 diabetes drug could slow progression of Parkinson‚Äôs disease ‚Äì 04/04/2024 at 8:50 p.m.
text:
((Automated translation by Reuters, please see disclaimer https://bit.ly/rtrsauto))
(Health Rounds is published Tuesdays and Thursdays. Think your friend or colleague should know about us? Send them this newsletter. They can also subscribe here.) by Nancy Lapid
Hello Health Rounds readers! GLP-1 drugs are in the news again, and not for weight loss. It is possible that drugs in this class can slow the progression of Parkinson‚Äôs disease. We also cover a potentially important discovery in the field of asthma, which could lead to new treatments, as well as an investigation into the prevalence of mistreatment of many mothers during childbirth in hospitals Americans.
Diabetes drug could slow progression of Parkinson‚Äôs disease
A diabetes drug in the same class of drugs widely used to treat obesity appears to slow the progression of early stages of Parkinson‚Äôs disease in a mid-stage trial, but with a potentially unacceptable rate of gastrointestinal side effects.
In the French trial, 156 patients who had Parkinson‚Äôs disease for less than three years and were receiving stable doses of drugs to treat symptoms received either daily injections of Sanofi SASY.PA‚Äôs GLP-1 agonist lixisenatide or a placebo.
After 12 months, the lixisenatide group had virtually no change in scores on a validated tool for assessing movement disorders in Parkinson‚Äôs disease, while the placebo group had a 3-point worsening of symptoms on a scale of 199 points, according to a report published Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.
The 3-point advantage in treated patients was still evident two months later, the researchers found. However, 46% of participants who received lixisenatide experienced nausea and 13% experienced vomiting.
‚ÄúThe incidence of side effects may pose a barrier to wider use of lixisenatide in the treatment of Parkinson‚Äôs disease,‚Äù wrote Dr. David Standaert, of the University of Alabama at Birmingham, in an editorial published in the site at the same time as the study.
Originally sold under the brand name Adlyxin, Sanofi stopped selling the drug in the United States in early 2023.
If a three-point improvement is the most that can be achieved, the benefit of lixisenatide could be limited, particularly because of side effects, Standaert said.
However, if the drug allows patients to remain stable while those who are not treated see their condition deteriorate by three points per year ‚Äúover a period of 5 to 10 years or more, then it could be a truly transformative treatment,‚Äù said Standaert.
Asthma attacks damage the lining of the airways
Asthma attacks actually damage the airways, new findings show, and preventing this damage could be the subject of new treatments, researchers say.
Although primarily considered an inflammatory disease in which the immune system attacks tissues, causing inflammation and mucus production, asthma is also known to involve bronchoconstriction ‚Äì the tightening of the smooth muscle that surrounds the airways. .
By studying human lung tissue and asthmatic mice, researchers at King‚Äôs College London discovered that muscle constriction compresses and destroys the epithelial cells that form the lining of the airways. This damage in turn promotes inflammation and mucus production often associated with an asthma attack, they explain in a report published Thursday in Science.
Researchers found that the standard treatment for asthma ‚Äì albuterol to open the airways and inhaled corticosteroids to control inflammation ‚Äì does not prevent damage to the airway epithelium and the inflammation that occurs. results after an asthma attack.
However, blocking the compression process and subsequent destruction of epithelial cells helped counteract the damage to the airways and significantly reduce the inflammatory response, they said.
‚ÄúThese results not only establish that bronchoconstriction is a pro-inflammatory stimulus, but they also open the way to new avenues of research that could inhibit the vicious cycle of mechanical damage and inflammation,‚Äù wrote another team. of authors in a commentary published on the site at the same time as the study.
1 in 8 American mothers report being abused during childbirth
Various forms of mistreatment during childbirth are common in U.S. hospitals, according to a study published Thursday in JAMA Network Open.
Researchers surveyed a representative sample of approximately half a million people who gave birth to a child living in 2020 in New York City and the states of Kansas, Michigan, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Utah and Virginia. Nearly 14% of the 4,458 study participants reported mistreatment during labor and delivery by responding to a validated questionnaire.
The most common forms of mistreatment reported were: being ‚Äúignored, denied a request for help, or not responding in a timely manner‚Äù, being ‚Äúyelled at or scolded‚Äù by health care providers, and have healthcare providers threaten ‚Äúto refuse treatment or force you to accept treatment that you did not want‚Äù.
This type of treatment was most commonly reported by women who were unmarried, insured by the Medicaid program for the poor, identified as LGBTQ, considered obese, with a history of substance use disorders, mental disorders, mood or domestic or intimate partner violence, as well as by women who have given birth by unplanned cesarean section.
‚ÄúMistreatment during childbirth has been widely documented in low- and middle-income countries, but this study shows that respectful maternal care is an important quality metric that we should also follow in the United States,‚Äù said in a press release the leader of the study, Jamie Daw, of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University, in New York.
Her team only looked at abuse during childbirth. New mothers in the sample may also have experienced mistreatment during pregnancy or the postnatal period, the researchers said.

author: Mary Kirby
title: Pittsburgh International to expand solar farm; eyes hydrogen hubRunway Girl
text: Known as one of the most sustainable and resilient airports in the world, Pittsburgh International Airport (PIT) in western Pennsylvania is looking to double the size of its solar farm. PIT‚Äôs current 8-acre farm with 9,390 solar panels is part of a three-year-old hybrid microgrid that also features an on-site natural gas power plant. But with vast acreage at its disposal, the airport is about to expand with many more solar panels. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got plenty of land. We sit on 8,800 acres at PIT, so we‚Äôve got a lot of space,‚Äù Christina Cassotis, CEO of PIT operator Allegheny County Airport Authority, told RGN on the sidelines of the International Air Transport Association‚Äôs World Sustainability Symposium in Coral Gables, Florida. ‚ÄúIt hasn‚Äôt been announced yet. It‚Äôs coming soon,‚Äù she revealed in reference to the solar farm expansion. Sitting atop the massive Marcellus Shale natural gas reserve, PIT is naturally advantaged ‚Äî beyond the expansive nature of its property. By embracing a hybrid approach to its microgrid, inclusive of solar, the facility has been able to dramatically reduce carbon emissions and slash electricity costs in a region that is otherwise known for its coal-heavy grid. ‚ÄúWhen I got there, they had just signed the lease with [natural gas company] CNX. So, when I took over that, that deal was already done. CNX had secured permission to extract natural gas on the property. And I think about a year after I got there, we started to see the results of that because we ‚Ä¶ get a royalty for that,‚Äù explained Cassotis. ‚ÄúSo, that has helped us with capital. It has helped us enormously to reinvest and that‚Äôs been really important for us. But we wanted to make sure that what we were doing is that we were investing not just financial resources, but investing these gas resources.‚Äù With a keen focus on improving resiliency and sustainability, a decision was taken early on to adopt a hybrid approach. ‚ÄúThere was no way it was not going to be hybrid,‚Äù Cassotis said. ‚ÄúHow do you send a message on sustainability and not have a renewable fuel source? So, to me it was non-negotiable; there was going to be a renewable resource for fuel that would power that microgrid in addition to the natural gas, because that‚Äôs the story we wanted to tell.‚Äù She continued: The story we‚Äôve always wanted to tell is that it‚Äôs a pathway, it‚Äôs a series of steps; it‚Äôs not a leap into a cleaner, greener future. And so, what can we do to be more resilient? Number one, that was the first goal, but we weren‚Äôt going to do it at the expense of finance or the expense of the environment. So, once we realized we could attain resiliency and lower our carbon footprint and lower our energy costs, which of course directly impacts the airlines‚Äô bottom line, then it was a no brainer. And so why? So, let‚Äôs tell the whole story. The whole story is that airports can do more to be sustainable. And we had the land for solar, so it just made a whole lot of sense. Nobody‚Äôs putting wind turbines up in an airport. The project is attracting interest from airlines and other airports alike. ‚ÄúWe are getting visits from folks to tour the microgrid‚Ä¶ Southwest Airlines actually came up and said, ‚Äòwe want to understand this so we can talk to some of our other airport partners about it,'‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe had the city of Houston come in to look at it for the airport in Houston and we have a group coming over from Japan actually. It‚Äôs fascinating. And we‚Äôve had other airports ask us about it and we just published a white paper. We‚Äôre getting interest but we haven‚Äôt seen anybody else do a microgrid yet.‚Äù Though PIT is presently in the midst of a major transformation ‚Äî one that aims to enhance the passenger experience for all travelers, including those with mobility challenges ‚Äî it is innovating in other eco-focused ways as the wider aviation industry works to achieve Net Zero by 2050. To that end, PIT in May announced it is working with CNX and KeyState Energy to accelerate regional and national hydrogen and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) developments, including with a proposed facility that would help catalyze hydrogen and SAF at scale ‚Äî with the anticipation that hydrogen-powered aircraft (and indeed other use cases for hydrogen) are forthcoming, and in acknowledgment of the massive role that SAF will play in helping industry meet its sustainability targets. ‚ÄúWe actually worked with a DOE-patented scientist in Pittsburgh to test how to create distributed hydrogen in a cost effective manner,‚Äù Cassotis told RGN in Florida. ‚ÄúWe actually did a one-year study with him and we‚Äôre looking for the funding. We‚Äôve talked to everybody from DOE to some of the airlines‚Äô venture funds about building the prototype, which would be about the size of the back of an 18-wheeler as opposed to a huge hydrogen hub. ‚ÄúBut how do you create distributed hydrogen in a cost effective manner? Yeah, we see ourselves as a hydrogen hub in ourselves. We have use cases for it, not just us, but our partners do , and we want to be at the forefront of that as well.‚Äù The Allegheny County Airport Authority chief and fellow staffers attended the IATA World Sustainability Symposium as they‚Äôre on the lookout for who in the ecosystem is making moves. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs thinking differently than we are? How do we learn? What else are we missing? How can we connect with folks who have the same ideas that we do or the same sort of value system around ‚Äòlet‚Äôs make this better‚Äô. I feel strongly that as an industry globally, we need to earn our right to grow,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I am an aviation aficionado. My dad was a Pan Am pilot. I care about this industry and I don‚Äôt want it hammered with the misperception that we‚Äôre not doing anything.‚Äù Related Articles: PIT is on the march with new airlines, routes and tech hub buzz ZeroAvia CEO Val Miftakhov reveals plan for possible IPO in 2026 JFK joins growing list of airports turning to the sun to cut emissions Sustainability and savings drive Pittsburgh Airport microgrid How Kempegowda International is harvesting sunlight and rainwater Pittsburgh International Airport‚Äôs recovery fueled by girl power Featured image credited to istock.com/bgwalker

Anthony Kazlowski, 49, died peacefully on Thursday, December 21, 2023. He was the loving husband of Michelle (Machado) Kazlowski.
He was born in Brockton, MA on January 23, 1974. He attended Bentley University where he received his Batchelor‚Äôs degree in Business.
Anthony had been employed by MFS Investment Management located in Boston, MA for over ten years. Also known as ‚ÄúKaz‚Äù amongst his friends, he enjoyed fishing and spending time with his family.

title: El efecto psicol√≥gico de vivir en ciudades contaminadas: ¬øcu√°l es?
text:
La contaminaci√≥n del aire no solo afecta nuestros pulmones, tambi√©n impacta de forma silenciosa y profunda nuestra mente. En un mundo donde m√°s del 55% de la poblaci√≥n vive en √°reas urbanas, entender las consecuencias de vivir en ciudades contaminadas es m√°s urgente que nunca. No se trata solo de enfermedades respiratorias o cardiovasculares, sino de impactos emocionales, cognitivos y sociales que alteran la calidad de vida.
Diversos estudios cient√≠ficos han demostrado que la exposici√≥n continua a altos niveles de poluci√≥n puede detonar s√≠ntomas de ansiedad, depresi√≥n e incluso deterioro cognitivo. Esta relaci√≥n entre contaminaci√≥n y salud mental ha empezado a ser reconocida por organismos internacionales como la OMS y la ONU, especialmente en contextos de desigualdad social. Vivir en ciudades contaminadas no es solo una cuesti√≥n ambiental, tambi√©n es una crisis silenciosa de salud p√∫blica.
¬øQu√© sucede en el cerebro al vivir en ciudades contaminadas? Cuando una persona est√° expuesta diariamente a aire contaminado, su sistema nervioso central comienza a reaccionar. Las part√≠culas finas en el aire pueden atravesar la barrera hematoencef√°lica, llegando directamente al cerebro y desencadenando procesos inflamatorios. Esto se ha asociado con mayor riesgo de enfermedades neurodegenerativas como el Alzheimer y el Parkinson.
Adem√°s, la exposici√≥n cr√≥nica al di√≥xido de nitr√≥geno y al material particulado se relaciona con cambios estructurales en regiones cerebrales como el hipocampo, clave para la memoria y el aprendizaje. Esto puede tener efectos particularmente graves en ni√±os, ni√±as y adolescentes, cuyo cerebro a√∫n est√° en desarrollo.
La neurociencia urbana est√° empezando a demostrar que vivir en ciudades contaminadas puede modificar la forma en que pensamos, sentimos y actuamos. El estr√©s urbano se ve amplificado por la poluci√≥n, y esto impacta directamente en nuestra salud mental y bienestar emocional.
Salud mental urbana: la otra cara de la contaminaci√≥n M√°s all√° de lo biol√≥gico, vivir en ciudades contaminadas tambi√©n genera una constante sensaci√≥n de malestar. El aire denso, la falta de visibilidad y los olores desagradables generan una carga psicol√≥gica persistente. Esto incrementa los niveles de estr√©s cr√≥nico, afecta la calidad del sue√±o y debilita el sistema inmunol√≥gico.
En barrios con mayores niveles de contaminaci√≥n se ha documentado un aumento en diagn√≥sticos de depresi√≥n, ansiedad y trastornos de √°nimo. Esto no es coincidencia: la relaci√≥n entre el entorno f√≠sico y el bienestar mental es cada vez m√°s evidente. Lugares sucios y descuidados tambi√©n influyen en nuestra percepci√≥n del valor que tiene nuestra vida y comunidad.
Vivir en ciudades contaminadas es, muchas veces, vivir en un entorno hostil para la mente. Cuando el ambiente externo no permite respirar con tranquilidad, el equilibrio interno tambi√©n se ve alterado. Esta es una alerta importante para quienes dise√±an pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas y espacios urbanos.
Impactos sociales: desigualdad ambiental y emocional No todas las personas sufren los efectos de la contaminaci√≥n de la misma manera. Quienes viven en zonas marginadas suelen estar m√°s expuestos a fuentes de poluci√≥n, como f√°bricas, tr√°fico intenso o basureros a cielo abierto. La desigualdad ambiental se traduce tambi√©n en una desigualdad emocional.
Las personas que viven en ciudades contaminadas y en contextos de pobreza suelen tener menos acceso a servicios de salud mental, espacios verdes o infraestructura adecuada para cuidar su bienestar. La falta de oportunidades para salir de estos entornos agudiza la sensaci√≥n de encierro, frustraci√≥n y desesperanza.
Por eso, hablar de salud mental en zonas urbanas tambi√©n implica hablar de justicia social. La responsabilidad social empresarial y gubernamental debe incluir acciones que reduzcan la exposici√≥n a contaminantes y fomenten la resiliencia emocional en las comunidades m√°s vulnerables.
¬øQu√© podemos hacer ante este panorama? La buena noticia es que no todo est√° perdido. Muchas ciudades han comenzado a tomar medidas para reducir la contaminaci√≥n y mitigar sus efectos sobre la salud mental. Desde promover el uso de transporte no motorizado, hasta aumentar los espacios verdes y la arborizaci√≥n urbana. Estas acciones pueden marcar una gran diferencia.
La conciencia ciudadana tambi√©n juega un papel fundamental. Informarnos sobre los riesgos de vivir en ciudades contaminadas y exigir cambios estructurales en las pol√≠ticas urbanas y ambientales es un acto de responsabilidad individual y colectiva. La salud mental debe ser parte integral de cualquier estrategia sostenible.
Adem√°s, desde la perspectiva de la responsabilidad social, las empresas pueden contribuir implementando pol√≠ticas internas que promuevan entornos laborales saludables, reducci√≥n de emisiones y programas comunitarios de salud emocional. El bienestar urbano es una tarea compartida.
Vivir en ciudades contaminadas es mucho m√°s que una molestia f√≠sica; es una experiencia que afecta el cerebro, las emociones y la convivencia social. Su impacto en la salud mental requiere atenci√≥n urgente desde el √°mbito de la salud p√∫blica, la pol√≠tica ambiental y la responsabilidad social empresarial.
Si queremos construir ciudades m√°s humanas, debemos reconocer el v√≠nculo entre aire limpio y mente sana. Apostar por entornos urbanos sostenibles no es solo una cuesti√≥n de ecolog√≠a, sino de salud mental colectiva. Porque respirar aire limpio es, tambi√©n, un derecho emocional.

author: Ignacio Escolar
title: El riesgo de corporativizaci√≥n de la decisi√≥n judicial
text:
Est√° suscitando cierto revuelo la iniciativa de una asociaci√≥n integrada por juristas, entre ellos jueces y magistrados, de elaborar unos modelos de auto suscitando una cuesti√≥n de constitucionalidad ante el Tribunal Constitucional o una cuesti√≥n prejudicial ante el Tribunal de Justicia de la Uni√≥n Europea sobre la Ley de Amnist√≠a. La iniciativa se justifica por sus promotores desde la premisa tajante de que se trata ‚Äìo se tratar√°, si se aprueba‚Äì de una ley que vulnera la Constituci√≥n y los Tratados de la UE. No voy a entrar en el (interesante y enormemente controvertido) fondo de la cuesti√≥n. No pretendo a√±adir m√°s argumentos a favor de alguna de las tesis que se enfrentan. Lo que s√≠ pretendo es poner de manifiesto el peligro de convertir la cuesti√≥n de constitucionalidad (o la cuesti√≥n prejudicial) en un instrumento ‚Äúcorporativo‚Äù del Poder Judicial, es decir, de trastocar su aut√©ntica e insustituible naturaleza jurisdiccional y hacer de ellas un sustituto de un recurso de inconstitucionalidad (o un recurso por incumplimiento) interpuesto ‚Äúpor los jueces‚Äù. O por un conjunto de ellos.
Los promotores de esta iniciativa saben que cada juez, cada tribunal, decidir√° por s√≠ mismo. Pero el resultado puede acabar siendo un deterioro m√°s de los instrumentos del Estado de derecho, al estandardizar y colectivizar una decisi√≥n que s√≥lo puede ser individual, y llevarlo al terreno doctrinal (o incluso pol√≠tico), abstracto, en el que el juez s√≥lo pusiera, por militancia o por pereza, su adhesi√≥n a un ‚Äúmovimiento‚Äù.
Existen gu√≠as y recursos para facilitar a un juez la tarea de formular ‚Äúcualquier‚Äù cuesti√≥n de constitucionalidad o una cuesti√≥n prejudicial. Es algo inobjetable: son tr√°mites de alguna complejidad que s√≥lo ocasionalmente en la vida de un juez se presentan, y es normal elaborar gu√≠as procedimentales.
Lo que es ins√≥lito es que se distribuyan masivamente a trav√©s del correo corporativo del poder judicial gu√≠as, instrucciones o recomendaciones para actuaciones posibles sobre un asunto determinado y concreto, incluyendo argumentaci√≥n jur√≠dica.
La cuesti√≥n de inconstitucionalidad no es un recurso de inconstitucionalidad. La cuesti√≥n prejudicial no es un recurso por incumplimiento. Los jueces no est√°n facultados, como tales, para interponer esos procedimientos, defendiendo una posici√≥n concreta. Respecto del recurso de inconstitucionalidad, pueden interponerlo un grupo de 50 diputados o senadores, o el Gobierno, o el Defensor del Pueblo, y en algunos casos las Comunidades Aut√≥nomas. No el Consejo General del Poder Judicial, ni 50 jueces.
